trial_identification.studytitle: A randomised clinical trial of different infusion rates of magnesium sulphate given prenatally to women.
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised clinical trial of different infusion rates of magnesium sulphate given prenatally to women for the prevention of side effects.

conditions.healthcondition: Magnesium sulphate therapy, prior to very preterm birth.

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Fetal medicine and complications of pregnancy

interventions.interventions: Women recruited will receive a magnesium sulphate intravenous infusion for 24 hours or until they give birth (whichever is the shorter) and will be randomised to different rates of administration of the intravenous loading infusion. 4 g magnesium sulphate over 60 minutes followed by 1 g per hour versus 4 g magnesium sulphate over 20 minutes followed by 1 g per hour.
interventions.comparator: Active control: 4 g magnesium sulphate administered over 20 minutes followed by 1 g per hour for 24 hours or until birth (whichever is the shorter).

primaryOutcome.outcome: Occurrence of any maternal adverse effects (clinical and self-assessed) during the magnesium sulphate infusion. This includes: arm discomfort with infusion, blurred vision, confusion/drowsiness, dizziness, headache, mild nausea/vomiting, mouth dryness, muscle weakness, palpitations, sweating, warmth/flushing, other reported side effects, tachycardia, respiratory depression.
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured at 20 minutes and 60 minutes after the start of the infusion, and at completion of the infusion.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Magnesium concentrations in cord blood at birth for the infant.
Total amount of magnesium sulphate given prior to birth
Cessation of treatment due to adverse effects attributed to the magnesium sulphate infusion.
Adverse cardiorespiratory effects of the infusion (defined as a respiratory rate <16/minute, sdrop in diastolic blood pressure >15mmHg, cardiac arrest, respiratory arrest, maternal death)
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Measured at 20 minutes and 60 minutes after the start of the infusion, and at completion of the infusion.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Women who are now recommended magnesium sulphate as per the National Clinical Practice Guidelines, and the South Australian Perinatal Practice Guidelines: a gestational age of less than 30 weeks where birth is planned or definitely expected within 24 hours. The women must have a singleton or twin pregnancy.

sponsorship.primarysponsorname: ARCH: Australian Research Centre for Health of Women and Babies, The Robinson Institute, The University of Adelaide
sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Level 1, Queen Victoria Building, Women's and Children's Hospital, 72 King William Street, NORTH ADELAIDE SA 5006

fundingsource.fundingname: ARCH: Australian Research Centre for Health of Women and Babies, The Robinson Institute, The University of Adelaide
fundingsource.fundingaddress: Level 1, Queen Victoria Building, Women's and Children's Hospital, 72 King William Street, NORTH ADELAIDE SA 5006

ethicsAndSummary.summary: This randomised clinical trial will assess whether a slower, compared with the standard infusion rate of the loading dose of magnesium sulphate, given to women at risk of very preterm birth at less than 30 weeks gestation for fetal neuroprotection, is effective in reducing maternal adverse effects of treatment.
ethicsAndSummary.publication: Maternal adverse effects with different loading infusion rates of antenatal magnesium sulphate for preterm fetal neuroprotection: the IRIS randomised trial. Bain ES, Middleton PF, Yelland LN, Ashwood PJ, Crowther CA. BJOG. 2014 Apr;121(5):595-603. doi: 10.1111/1471-0528.12535.
